occurrences.line_text: Frequented of these gentle Nymphes alwayes,
That we likewise should mylde and gentle be,
But gentle Shepheard pardon thou my shame,
So taking leaue of that same gentle swaine,
The gentle heart scornes base disparagement.
Which with those gentle shepherds here I wont to lead.
Her gentle hart, that now long season past
This gentle knight, from sewing his first quest,
For neuer more defaming gentle Knight,
Ne spareth he the gentle Poets rime,
In whom it seemes, that gentlenesse of spright
Against her Knight, her gentlenesse refused,
Did taste of pittie, neither gentlesse knew,
Could euer find, to grieue the gentlest hart on ground?
The gentlest knight, that euer on greene gras
Ah gentlest knight, that euer armour bore,
But as it falleth, in the gentlest harts
Now God thee keepe, thou gentlest Squire aliue,
Sith I enioyd the gentlest Dame aliue;
Ah gentlest knight aliue, (said Scudamore)
Which was the conquest of the gentlest Knight,
Thereby a Christall streame did gently play,
And gently grenning, shew a semblance glad
Which through the tre[m]bling leaues full gently playes
And gently askt, where all the people bee,
O gently come into my feeble brest,
Come gently, but not with that mighty rage,
Who gently answered, They entrance did desire.
So straungely passioned, and to her gently sayd,
Gently attempred, and disposd so well,
Where him to sleepe she gently would perswade,
And therefore them of patience gently prayd.
He gently gan him to demaund of all,
And euermore he gently did desyre,
He comming neare, gan gently her salute,
Her chearing vp, thus gently to her sayd;
But gently waking them, gaue them the time of day.
His daughter Genuiss' in marriage:
Forwasted all, till Genuissa gent
Saint George himself ye would haue deemed him to be.
The true Saint George was wandred far away,
And Patrone: thou Saint George shalt called bee,
Saint George of mery England, the signe of victoree.
Whereof Georgos he thee gaue to name;
That spat out poyson and gore bloudy gere
Gerioneo in fight:
And witnesse be Gerioneo found,
Gerioneos Seneschall
And sluggish german doest thy forces slake,
Thy selfe thy message doe to german deare,
And th'English Bath, and eke the german Spau,
Which when his german saw, the stony feare
He sent to Germanie, straunge aid to reare,
Those germans did subdew all Germany,
Those germans did subdew all Germany,
Besides subiected Fraunce, and Germany,
And gaped like a gulfe, when he did gerne,
Of Gyants race, the sonne of Geryon,
The image of his monstrous parent Geryone.
His sonne was this, Geryoneo hight,
Myld Titus and Gesippus without pryde;
And comming nigh, eftsoones he gan to gesse
That well she wist not what by them to gesse,
And goodly gan discourse of many a noble gest.
And famous far abroad for warlike gest,
Which of his name and memorable gest
Through his Heroicke grace, and honorable gest.
And her proud portance, and her princely gest,
Ne how to speake, ne how to vse his gest,
Each labouring t'aduance the others gest,
To winne me honour by some noble gest,
The Porter eke to her did lout with humble gestes.
Were painted faire with memorable gestes,
Of their braue gestes and prowesse martiall;
By signes, by lookes, and all his other gests.
And fitting gestures to her purpose frame;
To get, and nightly feare to lose his owne,
Or get his shield, his monstrous enimy
For which ye men do striue: few get, but many mis.
To get a snatch, when turned is his face.
Did get through great aduentures by him donne:
To get small thankes, and therewith many blames,
Did by great fortune get of her the sight;
And with her alwaies ride, till he another get.
Assembled, for to get the honour of that game.
As two fierce Buls, that striue the rule to get
They were full glad, in hope themselues to get her:
In great displeasure, that he could not get her.
Where they might tydings get of her estate;
And handling soft the hurts, which she did get.
To win her grace his libertie to get.
And triall, whether should the honor get.
And by his freedome get his free goodwill;
Which if I might by your good office get,
With gladfull hast, in hope of him to get
And brought the pillage home, whence none could get it out.
Long while he tug'd and stroue, to get it out,
For seldome seene, a trotting Stalion get
After aduentures, where they mote them get.
They fled, and fast into the wood did get:
To spy where he may some aduauntage get;
Doe fall together, stryuing each to get
The Nymph his mother getteth her,
Vaine Braggadocchio getting Guyons
When first I heard her horne sound with such ghastlinesse.
Full of sad feare and ghastly dreriment,
Who full of ghastly fright and cold affray,
The messenger of death, the ghastly Owle
A ruefull spectacle of death and ghastly drere.
On top whereof aye dwelt the ghastly Owle,
And scratcht her face with ghastly dreriment,
As ghastly bug their haire on end does reare:
She fled away with ghastly dreriment,
Made of a dead mans skull, that seem'd a ghastly sight.
Through ghastly horrour, and eternall shade;
And stared ghastly, some for inward shame,
Through suddein feare and ghastly drerihed,
As one with vew of ghastly feends affright:
For not of nought these suddeine ghastly feares
And there such ghastly noise of yron chaines,
Or other ghastly spectacle dismayd,
With nought but ghastly lookes him answered,
Which when she heard, and saw the ghastly fit,
With ghastly lookes and dreadfull drerihed;
But like a ghastly Gelt, whose wits are reaued,
But fled away with ghastly dreriment,
It made her stagger oft, and stare with ghastly eye.
And sternely him beheld with grim and ghastly looke.
Was with his ghastly count'nance nothing queld,
Who rising vp at last in ghastly wize,
Which when she sees with ghastly griefful eies,
Ye shall him Archimago find, I ghesse,
Him fortuned (hard fortune ye may ghesse)
And ghesse the man to be dismayd with gealous dread.
The Prince did wonder much, yet could not ghesse
ï¿½mylia well he lou'd, as I mote ghesse;
It seem'd a second paradise to ghesse,
Then gan Sir Calidore to ghesse streightway
Ne by inquirie learne, nor ghesse by ayme.
Whom at the first he ghessed by his looke,
Their harts she ghesseth by their humble guise,
And soone he came, as he the place had ghest,
He ghest his nature by his countenance,
Yet whether side was victor, note be ghest:
But chiefly by that yron page he ghest,
Of one loud crying, which they streight way ghest,
Greeting his graue: his grudging ghost did striue
What voyce of damned Ghost from Limbo lake,
Then groning deepe, Nor damned Ghost, (quoth he,)
Henceforth his ghost freed from repining strife,
Though greeued ghost for vengeance deepe do grone:
Goe guiltie ghost, to him my message make,
Then gins her grieued ghost thus to lament and mourne.
At last his mightie ghost gan deepe to grone,
As to doen outrage to a sleeping ghost:
Breathd out his ghost, which to th'infernall shade
That like a ghost he seem'd, whose graue-clothes were vnbound.
Or wandring ghost, that wanted funerall,
She shortly like a pyned ghost became,
Like to a ghost, that lately is reuiued
Let forth his wearie ghost and made an end of strife.
His wearie ghost assoyld from fleshly band,
Of th'vncouth sight, as he some ghost had seene,
That like a pined ghost he soone appeares.
Like ghost late risen from his graue agryz'd,
As if that euery dint the ghost would riue
And when my weary ghost with griefe outworne,
Like ruefull ghost, vnable once to stirre or moue.
Gaue leaue vnto his ghost from thraldome bound,
Whose grudging ghost was thereout fled and past,
With wounds, is ready to forgo the ghost:
Like troubled ghost did dreadfully appeare,
Does scorch not halfe so sore, nor damned ghoste
So her he deemes already but a damned ghoste.
And all about it wandring ghostes did waile and howle.
The trembling ghosts with sad amazed mood,
Whereas the damned ghosts in torments fry,
The groning ghosts of many one dismaide
The damned ghosts, that doe in torments waile,
But they to direfull death their groning ghosts did send.
Through which the damned ghosts doen often creepe
Where wicked ghosts do waile their former sin.
With that she askt, what ghosts there vnder ground
And to the other damned ghosts, which dwell
That a large purple streme adown their giambeux falles.
An hideous Giant, dreadfull to behold,
Like to a Giant for his monstrous hight,
Of hideous Giants, and halfe beastly men,
They brought forth Giants and such dreadfull wights,
And many Giants left on groning flore;
And those two brethren Giants did defend
He spide far off a mighty Giauntesse,
From slaughter of the Giaunts conquered;
Vppon that gibbet, which is there behind,
But when he saw her toy, and gibe, and geare,
All gan to iest and gibe full merilie
To seeke for succour of this Ladies gieft:
But other some by gift of later grace,
Embost with massy gold of glorious gift,
Foole (said the Pagan) I thy gift defye,
So shall you by one gift saue all vs three aliue.
Deliuered hath into your hands by gift;
Proffer thy giftes, and fitter seruaunts entertaine.
Who gaue him roiall giftes and riches rare,
With golden giftes and many a guilefull word
Yet deckt with wondrous giftes of natures grace,
Gaue goodly gifts, the signes of gratefull mynd,
With princely gifts of yuorie and gold,
The gifts of soueraigne bountie did embrace:
But shall with gifts his Lord Cadwallin pacify.
And gifts of heauenly grace he by him spide,
That all the gifts of grace and chastitee
And offered faire gifts t'allure her sight,
That will not vse his gifts for thanklesse nigardise.
Either through gifts, or guile, or such like waies,
And thousand pretious gifts worth many a pound,
Both gifts of God not gotten but from thence,
For when as neither gifts nor graces kind
She did allure with gifts and speaches milde,
And gaue them gifts and things of deare delight.
Life, freedome, grace, and gifts of great auaile,
And royall gifts of gold and siluer wrought,
O who may not with gifts and words be tempted?
Adornd with goodly gifts of beauties grace,
Of all her gifts, that pleasde each liuing sight,
But most of all, those three did her with gifts endew.
Those three to men all gifts of grace do graunt,
These three on men all gracious gifts bestow,
With heauenly gifts from heuen first enraced?
With looks, with words, with gifts he oft her wowed;
In gilden buskins of costly Cordwaine,
With gilden hornes, and flowry girlonds crownd,
Her bow and gilden quiuer lying him beside.
These goodly gilden armes, which I haue won in fight.
Clad all in gilden armes, with azure band
Foming with poyson round about her gils,
(Quoth she) how euer now in garments gilt,
With scutchins gilt and banners broad displayd:
Typhoeus ioynts were stretched on a gin,
And gin to pittie her vnhappie state,
Then gin the blustring brethren boldly threat,
Which two through treason and deceiptfull gin,
That now we foolish men that prayse gin eke t'enuy.
From their long vassalage gin to respire,
Busie (as seem'd) about some wicked gin:
To gin awake, and stirre his frozen spright:
And the great waters gin apace to swell,
(Sayd she) yet now I gin new life to feele,
And when I gin to feele decay of might,
But sith the Sunne now ginnes to slake his beames,
Quite ouerthrow, who now ginnes to despize
By vew of her he ginneth to reuiue
As when old father Nilus gins to swell
But when his later spring gins to auale,
When ruddy Phoebus gins to welke in west,
Then gins her grieued ghost thus to lament and mourne.
She gins her feathers foule disfigured
Now gins this goodly frame of Temperance
And her Gorgonian shield gins to vntye
Approching nigh, she gins to mend her pace,
And gins to spread his leafe before the faire sunshine.
Gins to abate the brightnesse of his beme,
Gins to looke vp, and with fresh wonted grace
They thought to gird, as best it her became;
And girded with a belt of twisted brake,
It would haue cleft him to the girding place,
Besides her golden girdle, which did fall
Tyde with her broken girdle, it a part
I found her golden girdle cast astray,
That Satyran a girdle did vptake,
Shall haue that golden girdle for reward,
For that rich girdle of faire Florimell,
A gorgeous girdle, curiously embost
The Ladies for the Girdle striue
Shall fall the girdle of faire Florimell:
That girdle gaue the vertue of chast loue,
Dame Venus girdle, by her steemed deare,
Cannot find one this girdle to inuest.
But th'emptie girdle, which about her wast was wrought.
But Florimells owne girdle, from her reft,
Likewise assayd, to proue that girdles powre;
And on his head an yuie girland had,
Then on her head they set a girland greene,
In her eternall trompe, with laurell girland cround.
Enuiron'd with a girland, goodly graced,
The comely virgins came, with girlands dight,
Whom all the people decke with girlands greene,
All deckt with crownes, & chaynes, and girlands gay,
Whilst freshest Flora her with Yuie girlond crownd.
A girlond for her dainty forehead fit,
A Rosy girlond was the victors meede:
Do worship her, as Queene, with oliue girlond cround.
About the fountaine like a girlond made;
Yet neuer any could that girlond win,
For euer with a flowring girlond crownd:
And winnes an Oliue girlond for her meeds:
Of which they still the girlond bore away,
And euery one did teare her girlond from her crowne.
The girlond of her honour did adorne:
Whiles all her Nymphes did like a girlond her enclose.
But like a girlond compassed the hight,
And girlond of the mighty Conquerours,
Fresh Alimeda, deckt with girlond greene;
To whom that day they should the girlond yield.
And like a girlond did in compasse stemme:
Crownd with a rosie girlond, that right well
Adorned all with gold, and girlonds gay,
Both those the lawrell girlonds to the victor dew.
With gaudie girlonds, or fresh flowrets dight
Now making girlonds of each flowre that grew,
With gilden hornes, and flowry girlonds crownd,
Gay girlonds, from the Sun their forheads faire to shade.
Eftsoones both flowres and girlonds farre away
With this faire flowre your goodly girlonds dight,
And decks the girlonds of her paramoures,
Girlonds of flowres sometimes for her faire hed
Faire Hellenore, with girlonds all bespred,
And their proud girlonds of tryumphant bayes
Their girlonds rent, their bowres despoyled all;
Both girlonds of his Saints against their foes offence.
Crowned with girlonds of immortall baies,
And with an yuie twyne his wast is girt about.
And girt in with two walles on either side;
And her small wast girt round with yron bands,
Ne spared he to giue her gold and rings:
Thee, foolish man, so rash a doome to giue?
Is then vniust to each his due to giue?
His office was to giue entertainement
And thristy giue to drinke, a worke of grace:
And had he lesse, yet some he would giue to the pore.
And if that no spare cloths to giue he had,
And warning giue, that enemies conspyre,
And said, Faire sonne, God giue you happie chance,
So courteous conge both did giue and take,
Loe I for pledges leaue. So giue me leaue to rest.
Take not away now got, which none would giue to me.
Sad verse, giue death to him that death does giue,
Sad verse, giue death to him that death does giue,
I giue thee life: therefore prostrated fall,
And giue you eke good helpe to their decay,
Giue no ods to your foes, but do puruay
To which right well the wise do giue that name,
Doe loue, where loue does giue his sweet alarmes,
O Atin, helpe to me last death to giue.
But giue me leaue to follow mine emprise.
Of grace I pray thee, giue to eat and drinke to mee.
More glory thought to giue life, then decay,
Who now shall giue vnto me words and sound,
Giue ouer to effect his first intent,
Thereof she vsd to giue to drinke to each,
And dreaded name shall giue in that sad day:
Shall giue th'enchaunter his vnhappy hire;
Her to restraine, and giue her good reliefe,
And they more fond, that credit to thee giue,
Because I could not giue her many a Iane.
Saying, but if she Mercie would him giue
And Peece, that vnto parley eare will giue,
But euery Satyre first did giue a busse
To giue him the reward for such vile outrage dew.
So both together giue a new allarme,
Giue it to her, for euer to remaine,
To giue him ground, (so much his force preuayled)
There did she pause, inforced to giue place,
Vnto your selfe, said they, we giue our word,
Ne doth she giue them other thing to eat,
Giue her great comfort, and some harts content.
Giue him more labour, and with streighter law,
For I resolue this siege not to giue ouer,
So blesse thee God, and giue thee ioyance of thy dreame
That the bold Prince was forced foote to giue
What guerdon can I giue thee for thy paine,
And way did giue vnto their gracelesse speed:
Wilt giue thy beard, though it but little bee?
Ne time would giue, nor any termes aby,
To giue faire colour to that Ladies cause in sight.
He gan to shrinke, and somewhat to giue place,
Giue salues to euery sore, but counsell to the minde.
Those goodly armes, he them away did giue
To giue him ground, and shift to euery side,
Whether more wary were to giue or ward the blow.
Into their neighbours borders; ne did giue
Her fleecie flocke; but Coridon most helpe did giue.
Giue leaue awhyle, good father, in this shore
You well reward, and golden guerdon giue,
Whereof her name ye then to her did giue.
Which giuen was to them for good intents;
Great grace that old man to him giuen had;
Me giuen by eternall destinie,
Was giuen all to lust and loose liuing,
For she was giuen all to fleshly lust,
To whom sweet Poets verse hath giuen endlesse date.
To Britomart was giuen by good right;
But ah she giuen is to vaine delight,
And yet such grace is giuen them from aboue,
Gainst womens loue, long giuen him in vaine.
And though vnto his will she giuen were,
Faith may be giuen, it is by them told,
And from the most, that some were giuen to the least?
The charge of Iustice giuen was in trust,
For nought was giuen them to sup or dyne,
For he had giuen streight commaundement,
Of her owne knight, had giuen him his owne due hire.
Giuen to me the spoile of this dead knight,
Had giuen them, whose griefe through suffraunce sore increast.
I giuen haue, liue in reproch and scorne;
Whether such grace were giuen her by kynd,
Giuen to Calidore, as his due right;
Vertue giues her selfe light, through darkenesse for to wade.
Vntroubled night they say giues counsell best.
Could neuer: will to might giues greatest aid.
And giues not rather cause it to forsake?
To him that giues thee life and libertie,
Of your gay sonne, that giues ye so good ayd
Therefore needs mote he liue, that liuing giues to all.
That death and life attonce vnto him giues.
And giues to him for wife.
He giues to this, from that he takes away.
That giueth comfort to her courage cold.
As giuing warning of th'vnwonted sound,
Giuing the bridle to her wanton will,
Giuing her dearest children one by one
To giust with that braue straunger knight a cast,
And them against came all that list to giust,
So foorth they went, and both together giusted;
As one for knightly giusts and fierce encounters fitt.
Paridell giusts with Britomart:
And solemne feasts and giusts ordain'd therefore.
Then the glad marchant, that does vew from ground
Right glad with him to haue increast their crew:
But when he heard of harme, he wexed wondrous glad.
And gently grenning, shew a semblance glad
They all as glad, as birdes of ioyous Prime,
Far off he wonders, what them makes so glad,
Glad of such lucke, the luckelesse lucky maid,
Who glad to gain such fauour, gan deuise,
With hasty ioy: to see him made her glad,
His owne coate he would cut, and it distribute glad.
The watchman wayting tydings glad to heare,
Glad signe of victorie and peace in all their land.
For she was inly glad her purpose so to gaine.
As euer of their loues they would be glad.
Who glad t'embosome his affection vile,
Thereat he wondrous glad, out of the path
She no lesse glad, then he desirous was
But with glad thankes, and vnreproued truth,
Wise Socrates, who thereof quaffing glad
So would I (said th'enchaunter) glad and faine
Glad was the knight, & with fresh courage fraught,
Had lost, he by him spide, right glad he grew,
Of my good sword and shield? The Palmer glad,
Which with her bounty and glad countenance
Might looke, that maketh euery creature glad,
The royall Mayd woxe inly wondrous glad,
They both conceiuing hope of comfort glad,
Sad life worse then glad death: and greater crosse
To scorne the ioy, that Ioue is glad to seeke;
As glad of that small rest, as Bird of tempest gon.
I glad by any meanes her grace to gaine,
Yet am I glad that here I now in safety am.
Abounded, being glad of so fit tyde
Ne ought but deare Bisaltis ay could make him glad.
She chearefull fresh and full of ioyance glad,
He glad of life, that lookt for death but late,
Content to heare him speake, and glad to rest withall.
Glad man was he to see that ioyous sight,
Whereof full glad for thirst, ech drunk an harty draught.
Instead of strokes, each other kissed glad,
Yet all were glad there Florimell to see;
They were full glad, in hope themselues to get her:
Who was right glad to gaine so goodly meed:
Full glad of so good end, to them drew nere,
But Scudamour now woxen inly glad,
Vnder his arme, as seeming wondrous glad,
Yet saw he often how he wexed glad,
Ne euer laught, ne once shew'd countenance glad;
Which when that Squire beheld, he woxe full glad
Whereof I glad did not gainesay nor striue,
He glad to satisfie, him selfe prepar'd
Ne ought on earth that merry is and glad,
Light Doto, wanton Glauce, and Galene glad.
And safe returne, he was full inly glad,
But Bracidas and Lucy were right glad,
They left behind them, glad to be so quit:
Glad from his companie to be so sondred;
The Fayrie glad to gaine his libertie,
Was glad to yeeld vnto his good request:
As glad to heare of armes, the which now she
She turnd her head aside, as nothing glad,
She was reuiu'd, and ioyd much in his semblance glad.
She, glad of spoyle and ruinous decay,
Whereof she glad, now needing strong defence,
Out of the pleasant soyle, and citties glad,
Yet glad at last to make most base submission,
Whom when he saw on ground, he was full glad,
As neither glad nor sorie for their sight;
And glad he was the slaughter so to stay,
Glad to be quit from that proud Tyrants awe,
Which I pursue, of whom I am right glad
Whereof she now more glad, then sory earst,
So all returning to the Castle glad,
